title: Global financial watchdogs issue warnings about stablecoins
text:
The Basel, Switzerland-based Financial Stability Board, which includes all the G20 economies, and the Paris-based Financial Action Task Force, a G7 initiative, both called for detailed overview and strong regulation of proposed digital coins like Facebook’s Libra. The coins could present broad systemic risks to global financial stability, they said, and catalyze illicit financial activity like money laundering. (Reuters)

Talking point: The declarations mark the latest point of pressure on the embattled Libra Association, whose five major payment partners—Mastercard, Visa, PayPal, Stripe and Mercado Pago—all recently quit the project. Dante Disparte, Libra’s head of policy and communications, said it won’t launch without regulatory approval, but a growing international consensus on the risks of fiat-tied digital coins like Libra seems to be pushing that possibility further out of reach. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is set to testify before the U.S. House Financial Services Committee on October 23, a meeting that will be closely watched by global regulators, as the CEO—who has refused to appear at multiple international hearings—will field questions on Libra, as well as Facebook’s impact on financial services and housing.
